content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting and uncommon, nice work

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun challenge
Very good clash for speed mode however I find it more complicated in code size mode

The statement could be made a lot clearer. The challenge should not be in understanding what to do but in programming a solution.

Here's a few adjustments I would do:
- It is too concise. Don't be afraid to be more verbose with the statement, make sure every element is perfectly clear. For example, instead of explaining both groups at the same time, you could split each definition in its own paragraph (e.g. An additive group is a group that contains a zero and any two members of the set added together give a result that is also in the set.);

- There's not enough examples. You should give an example of a GROUP* showing where to do the mod N and how to multiply every element (you could use a set of 3 elements here so the statement doesn't become unnecessarily long).
nice problem, though not necessary i think you should make the solution more readable and make some comments as well.
In groups, there is also an inverse requirement (or opposite in additive groups)! Your validator 1 is not a group because 3 has no inverse.
provide a better stub by adding the number of elements in the set and using loopline
Good point!  I updated the two GROUP* validators.  Let me know if you see any other issues.

Ok, but even if you changed the validators, technically the statement isn't asking yet to check if it's a group, right? (You don't need to check for the inverse). I think in fact you're asking to check if they are monoids (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semigroup) and semirings (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiring), but this would be probably confusing. Maybe you can just make abundantly clear, with a disclaimer, that for the sake of this problem that's the definition of group and ring, and leave an address for algebraists to file their complaints ;)

Nice!  Maybe I'll change the title to Monoids and Semirings, that sounds cooler.

I'm afraid the next observation will be that you can meet the identity requirement in other ways without the 0/1, and then on and on until we have a full textbook.  I'm torn between adding clarifications vs. keeping it as a simple introduction to a topic many might not have been exposed to before.
You're right, I was just being annoying I guess. The statement is clear enough as it stands.
